summary: The document details the CIA's operations, specifically Projects LIONION and KDAFGHAN, aimed at surveillance and intelligence gathering against the Cuban Embassy and Consulate in Mexico City. These projects involved photographic and physical surveillance, with agents monitoring movements and visitors. Project LIONION, a long-term support project, focused on fixed photographic, technical, and physical surveillance of the PBRUMEN Embassy and Consulate, aiming for photographic coverage, maintaining a listening post, dispatching surveillance teams, and fulfilling miscellaneous support requirements. The document outlines operational objectives, effectiveness, intelligence production, challenges, and future plans, including cost estimates for renewal. Project KDAFGHAN was terminated due to security issues, with agents resettled abroad.
key_findings: Projects LIONION and KDAFGHAN were focused on surveillance of the Cuban Embassy and Consulate in Mexico City.
These projects utilized agents for photographic coverage and physical surveillance, contributing to the compilation of dossiers on officials and supporting other Cuban operations.
The termination of Project KDAFGHAN was due to security considerations and blanket contamination, with agents being resettled in another country.
Project LIONION was considered essential for Cuban operations, providing timely operational information despite some operational challenges.
The documents highlight the importance of these projects in identifying new Cuban Embassy employees and verifying visits of Station assets to the Cuban Embassy.
Project LIONION is considered highly effective and essential by the Station, providing valuable photographic coverage and support for recruitment operations.
The project produced over 5000 individual photographs and approximately 8000 feet of pulse camera film in the past year.
Operational and administrative responsibilities were transferred from Howard A. KLER to Cornelius L. PEUVION in late January 1967 without any problems.
LIONION-1 was hospitalized for emergency surgery in June, leading to a temporary suspension of photographic coverage.
The Station plans to continue exploiting LIONION-1's experience and training, with an estimated cost of $11,258 for the renewal period.
